item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: Community Internet
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: Community Internet
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: https://muizenmesh.co.za/wp/web.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: Community Internet
item.content:encoded:
We are a community Internet project based in False Bay, Cape Town.

Our goal is to create a networking hub for residents of Muizenberg and surrounding areas such as Sunrise Beach, Marina de Gama, Costa de Gama, Lakeside & Capricorn Park.

Originally we wanted to set up a mesh-network, catering to Surfer's Corner and Palmer Rd, but the lock-downs stymied our initial goal. This would have provided access to information via a wifi network that acted as a limited internet gateway.

Our aims are thus a lot more modest and may change in the future.

Feel free to browse our site and to participate online.

If you would like to host your free site as a muizenmesh sub-site please register or contact the administrator.

Currently we are home to the Muizenberg Electricity Crisis Committee

item.dc:creator: Community Internet

item.title: Open Source Energy Unconference
item.dc:creator: Community Internet
item.content:encoded:
Hi there,

We’re excited that you want to participate in our unconference on Wednesday, 21 June. Our topic is Unlearning Energy Systems, which is about taking ownership of your energy supply, creating micro-grids, sharing energy, self-reliance, open-source, permissive and non-proprietary models, embracing systems change and finding innovative ways to relate to energy, amongst other things.

In case you have never been, an Unconference is an event that is participant-led. The organizers merely provide the framework so the participants can meet like-minded people and discuss the topics they are passionate about, share their perspectives, unlearn some limiting beliefs, form groups to take action together, etc. It’s basically all the best parts of a conference (e.g. having great conversations with interesting people during the coffee break) without all the boring parts. 

Who should attend?

Anyone who is passionate about the topics mentioned above. We would love to have you there to share your perspective, exchange experiences and learn from your knowledge on the wider topic of energy supply. 

What can you expect?

A highly interactive event that is co-created between all of us. We want to hear your questions and concerns, your ideas for solutions and your knowledge on the topic. Lead a discussion if you feel called to or participate in the discussions hosted by others.

What do you need to bring?

Please bring a laptop if you have one. Bring your questions and concerns, your ideas for solutions and your knowledge on the topic. 

What will be the outcome?

Each group will take notes on their discussion, capturing the most important points mentioned, the concerns, the ideas for solutions and the suggested next steps. Focus groups may be formed to realize the solutions that are found. All these notes will be shared on a public Google Drive for everyone to have access even to the discussions they weren’t part of.

Date & Venue

ZandVlei Lookout, Promenade Rd, Muizenberg, Cape Town, 21 June 2023 (Winter Solstice) registration from 8am, ends 1pm, event followed by Open Source Energy Festival until 4pm.

Word on our Facilitator

Carolin Zeitler has facilitated unconference events in Alto Paraiso, Brazil, Amsterdam, Netherlands and Doha, Qatar amongst others. She has facilitated interactive events of all kinds and sizes from 3 to 300 participants, retreated, workshops, World Cafes, Open Space events, Masterminds, etc. all across the world. She’s currently in South Africa to start a journey that is all about highlighting women-led social innovation across Africa, you can find out more about it on womenwhoimpact.co and theimpactcollective.eu/

REGISTRATION

item.title: Open Source Energy Festival
item.dc:creator: Community Internet
item.content:encoded:
Our Microgrid Future .

David Lipschitz

David Lipschitz is the founder of My Power Station Technology (Pty) Ltd which is a company that provides energy solutions for businesses and consumers. He is also the author of The Last Blackout a science fiction thriller.

David Lipschitz is a scientist. He has a Computer Science Honours degree from UCT and Rhodes, as well as a Cranfield MBA. He has operated an Information Technology business since 1994 and a Energy Business since 2008. In February 2009, David trained with Solar Energy International in Phoenix, Arizona and passed the North American Board of Certified Energy Professionals PV Associate.

In 2013, David was made an honorary lifetime member of the South African Alternative Energy Association (SAAEA) for his services and commitment to Renewable Energy in South Africa. In 2015, David was made a fellow of the SAAEA. Lipshitz has made his online books free on Smashwords for a limited period.

James Gien Wong

James Gien Wong is co-founder Stop Reset Go. a company that focuses on developing bottom-up, citizen-centric and rapid whole system change. He is also Electronic systems design, R+D, Commoner, Future Ancestor, Principal author of Deep Humanity protocol amongst other things.

Gien originally comes frm the world of electronic systems R+D, product development & marketing but has spent the last 10 years in bottom-up, rapid whole system change strategies for the globe.

He strongly believes that bottom-up, whole system change is possible through a combination of 1) a Human Inner Transformation (HIT) strategy combined with 2) a Social Outer Transformation (SOT) strategy that economically uplifts individuals and communities using regenerative and sustainable systems, processes and technologies.

He advocates a critical enabler to a larger local circular economy development strategy to overcome climate tipping points

Links

(1) Human Cogress,
(2) Redesigning the economy: from linear to circular and from me to we.
